name: Elementary French I
desc: Introduces the essential elements of French structure and vocabulary and aspects of French and francophone culture. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing. Students may not receive credit for both FREN 101 and FREN 111.

name: Elementary French II
desc: Continues the study of essential elements of French structure, vocabulary, and aspects of French and francophone culture. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing. Students may not receive credit for more than one of the following: FREN 102, 105 or 401.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 101.

name: French for High Beginners
desc: Accelerated course that covers FREN 101 and 102 for students with previous study of French.  Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing. Students may not receive credit for both FREN 105 and FREN 102 or 401.

name: Globalization and the French-Speaking World
desc: Gives students the opportunity to better understand the different facets of French-speaking regions across the modern world (including Africa, the West Indies, and North America) by looking at their geography, their historical and political development, varied cultural aspects, and their links with the United States. In English.

name: Intermediate French I
desc: Develops language skills for communication. Review of elementary French with increasing emphasis on reading and writing in the context of contemporary French and francophone culture. Students may not receive credit for both FREN 203 and 402. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 102, 105, or 401.

name: Intermediate French II in Context
desc: Continued development of language skills for communication through reading and discussion of texts and authentic materials. Emphasis on accurate grammar in written and oral expression. Students may not receive credit for both FREN 204 and 402. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 203.

name: Conversation I
desc: Introductory conversation for building oral proficiency while increasing awareness of French culture. Emphasis on vocabulary and grammatical accuracy; writing activities support speaking. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 204 or 402.

name: Literature and the French-Speaking World
desc: Skills for literary studies through poetry, theater, and prose from the Renaissance to the present. Lectures, discussions, and written assignments. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 204 or 402.

name: Cultural and Linguistic Diversity in the French-Speaking World
desc: French is evolving, changing, and becoming a multifaceted language, adapting to modernity and cultural realities. This course focuses on today's French across the French-speaking world and explores the diversity of relationships that French-speakers have with this shared heritage. Previously offered as FREN 250.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 204 or 402.

name: French Discoveries" of the Americas in Translation"
desc: Exploration of cultural relations between France and the Americas from early modern colonial encounters to 21st-century perspectives on diversity and multiculturalism.

name: Sex, Philosophy, and Politics: Revolutionary Literature in Translation
desc: Exploration of questions related to sex and gender during the French Revolution and their reflection in literature, philosophy, and art.

name: Food for Thought: The Culture of Cuisine in Modern France
desc: Exploration of French food culture in film, literature, and historical texts, examining gastronomy in relation to national and individual identity, immigration, cultural specificity, tradition and innovation, markets, sociability, and excess and lack.

name: French Composition and Grammar Review
desc: Recommended preparation, FREN 255, 260, or 262. Intensive grammar review and composition to improve accuracy and develop writing skills, using process and task-oriented approaches.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 204 or 402.

name: Healthcare in France and the Francophone World
desc: This course examines the evolution of the French healthcare system from its creation to today and the depiction of illnesses as well as healthcare workers in contemporary culture. Current issues related to health, illnesses, and healthcare in France and the Francophone World will be discussed.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 255, 260 or 262; corequisite FREN 300.

name: LAC Recitation
desc: Coregistration in a specified LAC course required.  Promotes foreign language proficiency across the curriculum. May not count toward the major or minor in French.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 204 or 402; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 4 total credits. 4 total completions.

name: Conversation and Composition II
desc: Intermediate conversation to expand speaking skills through vocabulary building, discussion of selected texts, and activities that produce conversation. Ongoing development of writing skills.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 255, 260, or 262; pre- or corequisite, FREN 300.

name: Communication Skills for Cultural Immersion
desc: Students will expand their active vocabulary, refine their mastery of grammar and hone communication skills to facilitate their cultural immersion during study abroad in Montpellier. Topics of current interest will allow students to explore French and regional culture while perfecting their written and oral expression and comprehension. Open only to students in France.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 300.

name: French University Methodology through Literature
desc: Open only to students in Montpellier, France. Introduction to French literature through the study of a selection of representative texts. Prepares students for the academics required at a French university. Students will also gain knowledge and experience of the intellectual culture and educational organization of France.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 300.

name: Imposteur!: Faking and False Identities in French and Francophone Drama and Film
desc: Examines how French-language plays and films explore questions of identity through stories of imposture, disguise, cross-dressing, and mistaken identity. Authors studied include Molière, Marivaux, De la Chenelière, and others.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 255, 260, or 262; Pre- or corequisite, FREN 300; permission of the instructor for students lacking the requisites.

name: Business French
desc: Practice of vocabulary and discourse strategies pertinent to business-related activity in French. Readings and discussions emphasize cultural awareness for interaction in cross-cultural settings.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 255, 260 or 262; pre- or corequisite, FREN 300; permission of the instructor for students lacking the requisites.

name: Crime and Literature in French and Francophone Contexts
desc: This course explores the depiction of crime in literature: from medieval tricksters and classical tyrants to romantic crimes of passion; from the destruction of social and ethical codes to the global victims of (civil) war.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Approaches to French and Francophone Studies
desc: Focuses on important aspects of the culture, society, history, geography, politics, art, and literature of France and its regions as well as the French-speaking world.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Current Societal Issues: France and Beyond
desc: Oral communication and composition on contemporary topics in French and francophone cultures. Study of cultural texts, articles from the French press, and video documents.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Francophone Drama and Multimedia Productions
desc: French-language theater. Specific topics to be announced in advance by the instructor. Previously offered as FREN 380.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300, and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Francophone Poetry and Slam
desc: Specific topics to be announced in advance by the instructor. Previously offered as FREN 381.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300, and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Visual Francophone Studies
desc: Specific selections announced in advance by the instructor. Previously offered as FREN 382.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300, or one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Introduction to Translation
desc: Theory and practice of translation through a dual approach of conceptual readings and classroom discussion and workshops in interdisciplinary fields. Emphasizes cultural role of the translator as mediator.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: French and Francophone Studies to 1789
desc: An overview of literatures, cultures, and histories of the French-speaking world from Antiquity to 1789.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: French and Francophone Studies since 1789
desc: An overview of literatures, cultures, and histories of the French-speaking world since 1789.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Francophone Literature and Film
desc: Readings in francophone literatures from literary and cultural perspectives. Areas of study may vary (African, Canadian, European, etc.).
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Identity and Nationhood in Québécois Literature
desc: The evolution of identity and nationhood in Québécois literature from the 1960s to the present. Includes the study of francophone literature of immigration in Québec.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: The Evolution of Frenchness since WWII
desc: How wars, women's movements, immigration, and globalization have influenced the notion of Frenchness.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: French and European Transmigrations: Global Contexts
desc: Interdisciplinary studies of France's role in the construction of European identity.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Special Topics in French and Francophone Studies
desc: Possible topics include cinema, transnational francophone literatures, gender studies. In English.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Franco-Asian Encounters
desc: Examines the cultural encounters between France and Vietnam and China, the socio-historical context of French colonialism in Vietnam, and the literary and cultural production to which it gave rise.

name: French New Wave Cinema
desc: Films of the major directors of the French New Wave of the 1950s through the 1970s, including Jean-Luc Godard, François Truffaut, and Eric Rohmer. Examination of earlier films informing these directors. The impact of the New Wave on global cinema. In English; students may do written work in French for major/minor credit. Recommended preparation for majors/minors, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262; non majors, CMPL 143.

name: Paris/Versailles: The Court and the City in the 17th Century
desc: Seventeenth-century Paris and Versailles serve as the basis for considering the construction of cultural centers and peripheries; the role of style, taste, and etiquette in the fabrication of social identities; the theatricality of life at court and in the city; and the relationship between political power and aesthetics.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: History of French Cinema I: 1895-1950
desc: Study of French cinema from 1895 through 1950, including early French film, silent cinema, surrealism, poetic realism, and postwar cinema. Concepts and vocabulary for film criticism. Conducted in English; students may do written work in French for major or minor credit. For French majors and minors, recommended preparation is FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262; for all other students, recommended preparation is CMPL 143.

name: History of French Cinema II: 1950 to the Present
desc: Study of French cinema from 1950 to the present, including postwar cinema, the New Wave, and the French film industry in the age of globalization. Concepts and vocabulary for film criticism. Conducted in English; students may do written work in French for major or minor credit. For French majors and minors, recommended preparation is FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262; for all other students, recommended preparation is CMPL 143.

name: Special Topics in French and Francophone Studies
desc: Examines selected topics in French and francophone studies. Content varies by semester and instructor.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Research for Advanced French Students
desc: Research project on topic agreed upon by the student and faculty member. Includes bibliographic work and research approaches.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Beginning Accelerated French
desc: Covers levels one and two of the basic language sequence in one semester.  Designed for highly motivated undergraduate/graduate language learners, especially those who have experienced success with learning another language. Intensive approach to developing all skills but with an emphasis on speaking. Students may not receive credit for both FREN 401 and any of the following: FREN 101, 102, 105.

name: Intermediate Accelerated French
desc: A continuation of FREN 401. Covers levels three and four in one semester. Develops all skills, with increasing emphasis on reading, writing, and cultural analysis. Designed for highly motivated undergraduate/graduate language learners, especially those who have experienced success with learning another language. Prepares students for advanced courses. Students may not receive credit for both FREN 402 and any of the following: FREN 203 and 204.

name: Advanced Composition
desc: Review of advanced grammar. Exercises in translation from English into French of literary and critical materials. Free composition and training in the use of stylistic devices.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: French for the Health Professions
desc: Aimed at health care professionals in a variety of fields, this class is designed to help them practice, consolidate, and improve their language skills, while encouraging students to develop a fuller understanding of health care systems in French-speaking regions of the world and to compare conditions with those in the United States. This course does not fulfill the FL requirement and does not count for the French major or minor.

name: Old French
desc: An introductory course designed to enable students to read medieval texts with rapidity and accuracy. Phonology, morphology, semantics, and syntax.

name: Literary and Cultural Theory in France
desc: A study of structuralist and poststructuralist methods in poetics, semiotics, psychoanalysis, sociology, and philosophy.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Muslim Women in France and the United States
desc: This class will follow Muslim women's experiences and changing roles in France and the United States from the 1970s through today.

name: 19th-Century Literature and Culture
desc: Intensive study of a single major author of the romantic or postromantic period. The subject changes from year to year among writers in the different literary genres.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.

name: Special Topics in French and Francophone Studies
desc: Examines selected topics in French and francophone studies. Content varies by semester and instructor.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one of the following: FREN 255, 260, or 262.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Research Methods in French and European Studies
desc: Provides training in research methodology either for a B.A. honors or M.A. thesis topic related to contemporary European studies. Students will learn to conceptualize an original research project and to identify and assess the current intellectual debates in their chosen areas of research.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: Cultural Wars: French/United States Perspectives
desc: This course examines the limits of universalism in today's multicultural" France and how the European Union affects French universalism and French resistance to identity politics."
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: African Francophone Cinema
desc: Study of the production of films from francophone sub-Saharan and North African communities.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: 20th- and 21st-Century French Literature and Culture
desc: Studies of a single author, a literary movement, or an aesthetic movement from the avant-garde to postmodernism.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Social Networks: Technology and Community in Modern France
desc: Exploration of the interaction between technology and sociability in 19th- through 21st-century French literature, with an emphasis on questions of modernization, industrialization, colonization, globalization, subjectivity, and ethics. Taught in French.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: French Middle Ages
desc: Readings in a variety of medieval texts in light of contemporary literary theory.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Postmodernisms
desc: Theory, literary texts, films, and cultural phenomena associated with postmodernism and the interaction of art, philosophy, film, literature, and popular culture.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Writing the Mediterranean
desc: Explores early modern literary representations of the Mediterranean as a space of cross-cultural encounter, exchange, rivalry, and negotiation.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: Crossing Gazes: Multidirectional and Conflicting Memories of Algeria
desc: Focus on contemporary fictions and films, and the writing of history from both the French (French-Algerian or Pieds noirs
Prereqs: French draftees) and the Algerian sides.
GenEd: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: BN, GL.
Grading: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: French Renaissance Literature and Culture
desc: Recommended preparation, FREN 370. Interdisciplinary seminar on a cultural topic or a theme through readings in literary and nonliterary texts.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Poetry of the French Renaissance
desc: Recommended preparation, FREN 370. Major currents in French Renaissance poetry: the Rhétoriqueurs, the break with the Middle Ages, Italian influences, the formation of the French Renaissance sonnet, poetry and gender, poetry and politics, the Pléiade. Clément Marot, Maurice Scève, Louise Labé, Olivier de Magny, Pierre de Ronsard, Joachim Du Bellay.

name: Studies in the Anglo-French Renaissance
desc: Recommended preparation, FREN 370 (for students taking the course for French credit), or one course from ENGL 225 to ENGL 229, or one course from CMPL 120 to CMPL 124. Study of French-English literary relations in the Renaissance, focusing on literary adaptation and appropriation, poetics, political writing, and related areas. Conducted in English; students may do written work in French for major or minor credit.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: History of the French Language
desc: The phonology, morphology, and syntax of French are traced from the Latin foundation to the present. Lectures, readings, discussions, and textual analysis.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300, and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: French Phonetics and Phonology
desc: Study of the sound system and prosody features of standard French, emphasizing practical application in a variety of oral activities. Requires learning linguistic terminology and the phonetic alphabet
Prereqs: Prerequisite, FREN 255, 260, or 262; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Structure of Modern French
desc: Introduction to phonology, morphology, and syntax of modern standard French. Application of modern linguistic theory to the teaching of French.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300, and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: 20th- and 21st-Century Francophone Literature and the Visual Arts
desc: Evolution of francophone literature from a literary and cultural perspective (Maghreb, Africa, Caribbean Islands, and Canada).
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Francophone Cultural Studies
desc: An examination of national and transnational identity within European culture and recent economic and ethnologic changes in Western Europe and France.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: 18th-Century French Literature and Culture
desc: Intensive study of a major 18th-century writer.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the requisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Libertinism and Sexuality
desc: In-depth study of the genealogy of the concept of libertinage as a philosophical discourse and aesthetic manifestation.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the requisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Studies in French Cinema
desc: Recommended preparation for French majors and minors, FREN 300 and one of FREN 255, 260, or 262; for all other students, CMPL 143. Themes, periods, and movements in the history of French cinema. The course may cover early cinema, silent film, poetic realism of the 1930s, postwar cinema, the French New Wave, or late twentieth- and early twenty-first century cinema. Taught in English or French. See department announcements for current topic and language of instruction.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Special Topics in French and Francophone Studies
desc: Examines selected topics in French and francophone studies. Content varies by semester and instructor.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the requisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: French for Reading
desc: French language for reading. For students with no background in French or those needing a review of grammatical structures and vocabulary in preparation for the reading knowledge exam for graduate degrees (FLPA).

name: French Novelists of the 20th Century
desc: Evolution of the novel in France up to the nineties.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the requisites.

name: Framing Identities: Franco-Arab Transvisual Transcultural Contexts
desc: This course focuses on the representation of identities in Franco-Arab contexts and in various artistic productions (fiction, photography, paintings, comics, films, etc.), with a special focus on Algeria, Tunisia, France, Lebanon, and Québec.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: 17th-Century French Literature and Culture
desc: In-depth study of a particular aspect of 17th-century literature and culture. Possible topics are the court and its elsewhere, Frenchness and foreignness in the 17th century, theater and theatricality, enchantment and disenchantment.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Literature and Enlightenment, 17th -18th Centuries
desc: This seminar examines 17th- and 18th-century French literature in relation to the intellectual, social, and political movements of the Enlightenment. See department announcements for current topic and reading list. In French. Primarily for graduate students; advanced undergraduates may enroll with permission of the instructor.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Diaspora and Transculturalism in Québécois Literature
desc: Evolution of identity and nationhood in Québécois literature from the 1960s to the present, including the study of the literature of immigration (diasporic or littrature migrante).
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300 and one additional course above FREN 330; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Special Topics in French and Francophone Studies
desc: Examines selected topics in French and francophone studies. Content varies by semester and instructor.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, FREN 300, and 370, 371, or 372.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Honors Thesis in French
desc: Required of students reading for honors. Preparation of an essay under the direction of a member of the faculty. Topic to be approved by thesis director in consultation with honors advisor.

name: Honors Thesis in French
desc: Restricted to senior honors candidates. Second semester of senior honors thesis. Thesis preparation under the direction of a departmental faculty member.

name: French Drama and Film
desc: Semiotic readings in French and Francophone theater at the crossroads of cultures from the avant-garde to postmodernism.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: French Feminist Theory
desc: An introduction to feminist literary theory, focusing on feminist writings from France (in translation) and their sources in psychoanalysis and poststructuralism. Anglo-American counterparts and adaptations of the French theorists in the United States will also be treated.

name: 17th-Century Drama
desc: Readings in 16th and 17th-century French theater, Crébillion père and Voltaire. Selection of texts will be announced by the instructor.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Philosophers of the Enlightenment
desc: Intellectual currents (religious, scientific, epistemological) and morals as reflected in such writers as Bayle, la Mettrie, Condillac, Helvétius, d'Holbach, the Encyclopedists, and others.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Franco-Asian Encounters
desc: Cultural encounters between France, Vietnam and China and overview of the French presence in Vietnam from the 1880's to the end of the colonial period in 1954.

name: Special Topics in French and Francophone Studies
desc: Examines selected topics in French and francophone studies. Content varies by semester and instructor.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: French 19th-Century Post-Romantic Poetry
desc: A study of the evolution of poetry and poetics in modernity beginning with Baudelaire.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: The French Realistic and Naturalistic Novel
desc: A study of major realistic and naturalistic novelists (Flaubert, the Goncourts, Daudet, Zola, Maupassant, and Huysmans).
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: French Brief Fiction of the 19th Century and/or 20th Century
desc: A study of short narrative as a hybrid genre from a literary and cultural perspective.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Fin-de-Siècle Literatures
desc: Fiction from the 1880s through WWI and its aftermath: modernity (the1850s), decadence, naturalism, the Avant-garde, and the belle époque.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Special Readings
desc: Doctoral students only.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Seminar
desc: Topic determined by instructor and announced in advance.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Master's (Non-Thesis)
desc: Master's Thesis Substitute
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.

name: Doctoral Research and Dissertation
desc: Research in a special field under the direction of a member of the graduate faculty.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit.
